author: Special Correspondent
text:
“They will be given adequate protection”

Technicians from Bharat Electronics Limited, Bengaluru, calibrating electronic voting machines in a godown at Sripuram in Tirunelveli on Wednesday.— Photo: A. Shaikmohideen

A total of 709 booths in the district had been identified as ‘sensitive’ based on a survey conducted by the police and the past experience, Collector M. Karunakaran said.

During an informal chat with reporters after inspecting the calibration of electronic voting machines stocked at Tamil Nadu Warehousing Corporation’s godown at Sripuram here on Wednesday, Dr. Karunakaran said that the polling stations, which had been categorised as ‘sensitive’, would be given adequate protection by deploying policemen and the Central forces that would arrive at the district on the eve of election so as to ensure free and fair polls.

A total of 9,513 EVMs, including 5,053 control units and 4,460 ballot units, had been brought to Tirunelveli from Gujarat and Maharashtra, and 5,000 more units would shortly arrive in Tirunelveli from Haryana, the Collector said.

A team of six technicians from Bharat Electronics Limited, Bengaluru, began the first-level checking of all the EVMs’ ballot and the control units and would calibrate the machines, if necessary.

“The EVMs will be sent to 2,929 booths after the first-level check with due police protection,” Dr. Karunakaran said.

Tirunelveli Revenue Divisional Officer P. Fermi Vidhya accompanied the Collector.
title: 709 booths ‘sensitive’ in Tirunelveli district
